section.name: Accounting of purchase, prepayments, payments tracking.
section.p: Keywords: Accounting of purchase, prepayments, sales taxes from purchase, payments tracking.
section.h4: Sales taxes payed for raw material (producing USA).
section.p:
According IRS 535 Business Expenses, Page 18 sales taxes that Bob paid for materials are business expenses (sales taxes are included into material cost), i.e. they are deducting income tax:
... Any sales tax you pay on a service for your business, or on the purchase or use of property in your business is treated as part of the cost of the service or property. If the service or the cost or use of the property is a deductible business expense, you can deduct the tax as part of that service or cost. If the property is merchandise bought for resale, the sales tax is part of the cost of the merchandise. ... * I think here term "property" also means materials and supplies (as well as merchandise), any way for any seller these all means "goods/merchandise". * term "deduct an expense" means that you can deduct its cost (part or whole) from gross income, so as a result the tax is decreased. deducting in double entry system usually makes with: Credit [An Asset Account] Debit [An Temporary Gross Income Expense Account] for deducting amount at the end of accounting period all temporary gross income expenses/revenues accounts are closed on gross income account (or directly on retaining earnings/loses)
That is sales taxes from purchase is included into inventory and they become expenses automatically as part of Cost Of Goods Sold (method FIFO in this case). So Bob should set accounting settings "Extract sales taxes from purchase" to No, and set "is used" to No for method "PurchaseInvoice, Debit SalesTaxFromPurchase per Tax.":
Also he should set "is used" to No asset account Sales Tax From Purchase. Then he should fill inventory item tax category and set sales tax for each material. Purchase invoice will extracts taxes cost into Sales Tax From Purchase account.

If you have to use different method to account sales tax from purchase, then set accounting settings "Extract sales taxes from purchase" to Yes, and set "is used" to Yes for method "PurchaseInvoice, Debit SalesTaxFromPurchase per Tax." Also you should set "is used" to true asset account Sales Tax From Purchase. This is required in case of using "inventory capitalized costs" method (for USA example IRS 538, Page 18 Uniform Capitalization Rules). Capitalized cost became expenses partially depends of ending inventory. For example a factory produces 1000 notebook, they cost (capitalized) is 20000, at the end of period 900 notebooks are sold. So 90% of costs (18000) is deducting the tax, the rest 2000 remained on assets.
For many other countries sales taxes (e.g. VAT) from purchases is always extracted from goods/service cost and they are deducting themselves (taxes from sales, not deducting income tax).
Sales taxes imposed on the buyer from your sales of your goods/service are extracted from sales revenue, and you have to pay them, this rule is applied in all countries.
